title: The South Sea Bubble: When a Nation Gambled
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on The South Sea Bubble: When a Nation Gambled.

hook.text: In 1720, Isaac Newton lost Â£20,000 in the South Sea Bubble â€” roughly $4 million today.

buildup.text: The South Sea Company offered to take over Britain's national debt in exchange for a trade monopoly.

discovery.text: The company had almost no real trade. Its value was based on promises, bribery of politicians, and mass hysteria.

twist.text: Newton invested early, sold for a profit, then bought back in at the peak.

climax.text: The crash wiped out thousands. Parliament investigated but most corrupt officials were never punished. Sound familiar?

punchline.text: Newton said: 'I can calculate the motion of stars, but not the madness of men.'

quiz.question: Why did Isaac Newton lose money in the South Sea Bubble?
options: He sold for profit then reinvested at the peak, driven by fear of missing out
